Below is a collection of some of the things we read and discussed at Twine this month: 1) States and Feds Mull Data Privacy Laws Washington, Kentucky, New Jersey, New Mexico, New York, North Dakota, Utah, and Virginia are all considering joining California in enacting data privacy laws. At the federal level some bills have also been put forth, but nothing is showing traction, leaving states to take regulation on themselves. Related: North Dakota’s Privacy Law Has Been Reduced to a Study, and the Creator Is Not Happy Related: Washington State Proposes Data Privacy Bill 2) France Fines Google $57M Under GDPR France draws first blood under the GDPR, levying a fine against Google for failing to comply with requirements around choice and notice in the set up of new Android phones. Facebook, Instagram, and WhatsApp face investigations in other parts of the EU. 3) Good Data Practices Are Good for Business A Cisco study finds that good data privacy practices promote better customer relations and provide a sales boost. 4) January Was a Bad Month for Facebook In January, Facebook lost trusted status with Apple, and it was revealed that they let children make purchases within their platform. Additionally, their revealed plan to merge Instagram, WhatsApp, and Facebook is raising data privacy concerns. title_html: Spotlight on Privacy: What We’re Reading
html:
Homepage
Homepage
Sign inGet started

Spotlight on Privacy: What We’re Reading

Elliott Easterling
Mar 9

Want to keep up on the latest in data privacy? Below is a collection of some of the things we read and discussed at Twine this month:

1) States and Feds Mull Data Privacy Laws

Washington, Kentucky, New Jersey, New Mexico, New York, North Dakota, Utah, and Virginia are all considering joining California in enacting data privacy laws. At the federal level some bills have also been put forth, but nothing is showing traction, leaving states to take regulation on themselves.

Related: North Dakota’s Privacy Law Has Been Reduced to a Study, and the Creator Is Not Happy

Related: Washington State Proposes Data Privacy Bill

2) France Fines Google $57M Under GDPR

France draws first blood under the GDPR, levying a fine against Google for failing to comply with requirements around choice and notice in the set up of new Android phones. Facebook, Instagram, and WhatsApp face investigations in other parts of the EU.

3) Good Data Practices Are Good for Business

A Cisco study finds that good data privacy practices promote better customer relations and provide a sales boost.

4) January Was a Bad Month for Facebook

In January, Facebook lost trusted status with Apple, and it was revealed that they let children make purchases within their platform. Additionally, their revealed plan to merge Instagram, WhatsApp, and Facebook is raising data privacy concerns.

Related: Apple Boots Facebook from Its Trusted Company Program

5) Inside the Lobbying War over California’s Privacy Law

Before the CCPA goes into effect at the end of this year, tech industry lobbying groups are spending time and money to make the law easier to comply with.

6) Focusing Data Security Around Consumer Privacy Concerns

Many data security plans focus on protecting the company, but data security teams should also focus on the increasing awareness of consumers about the vulnerability of their data.

At Twine, we believe protecting consumer data and respecting consumer choice are the bedrock of TrueData. Contact us to find out more about how we weave data privacy into every part of our business.

  • Privacy
  • Data Privacy
  • Consumer Choice
  • Data Security
  • Data

  • Elliott Easterling

    Founder and CEO of TrueData. www.TrueData.co
